attributeDescriptions.prop: the sample proportion you are studying
attributeDescriptions.P: the "P-value," the probability that, if the null hypothesis were true, we would see a value of the test statistic this extreme.
attributeDescriptions.CImin: the lower bound to the confidence interval
attributeDescriptions.CImax: the upper bound to the confidence interval
attributeDescriptions.alpha: the probability we use to decide if a P-value is "significant." Use significance with caution.
attributeDescriptions.conf: the value, in percent, used to compute the confidence interval
attributeDescriptions.t: the t statistic, the z value divided by the square root of N
attributeDescriptions.z: the z statistic: the difference from the hypothesized value divided by the sample standard deviation
attributeDescriptions.chisq: the chi-squared statistic. It measures how far a set of counts is from the "expected" value.
attributeDescriptions.F: the F statistic. It measures how mauch variation is between groups as opposed to within groups.
attributeDescriptions.tCrit: a critical value for t: the value that corresponds to the probability alpha
attributeDescriptions.zCrit: a critical value for z: the value that corresponds to the probability alpha
attributeDescriptions.chisqCrit: a critical value for chi-squared: the value that corresponds to the probability alpha
attributeDescriptions.FCrit: a critical value for the F statistic
attributeDescriptions.value: the hypothesized value you are comparing your test statistic to
attributeDescriptions.outcome: the name of the left-hand (outcome) variable
attributeDescriptions.predictor: the name of the right-hand (predictor) variable, even if it's not being used to predict anything
attributeDescriptions.procedure: what kind of statistical procedure was used
attributeDescriptions.SSR: the sum of squares of residuals calculated between the groups
attributeDescriptions.SSE: the sum of squares of errors, that is, calculated within the groups relative to the group means
attributeDescriptions.SST: the total sum of squares, SSR + SSE
attributeDescriptions.dfTreatment: the degrees of freedom among the groups, i.e., the number of groups minus one.
attributeDescriptions.dfError: the degrees of freedom within the groups, a little less than the number of cases.
attributeDescriptions.mean: the mean of the attribute you're looking at
attributeDescriptions.diff: the difference of means (or proportions) you are studying
attributeDescriptions.SE: the standard error of the mean (or proportion)
